bibl.note: On December 1, 1891, Whitman received a letter from J. Armory Knox (1851–1906), the head of the Universal Knowledge and Information Bureau of New York; the letter was written on the Bureau's stationery. Whitman tore that letter in half, and then wrote this letter to Bucke on the verso of the bottom half of Knox's letter.

body.p: A bad week (ab't as bad as any)—Dr L absent sick but a suspision of easier last night—bladder suffering mostly, but other things—yr's rec'd—Thanks—H Staff's wife & children (fine ones) call this mn'g—have just drink'd a glass of buttermilk—cool & sunny—no final set'ment of the tomb bill—no final L of G's yet—nothing more of the Eng: publishing proposal—am sitting here in g't chair same inertia ab't same—but feel as if I were a great unmitigated mass of perturbation & belly-ache—I enc: Logan Smith's f'm Paris (good friendly yn'g fellow)—some NY friend has just sent a nice big box of oranges & grapes—Horace well—Mrs: D and Warry kind always—I have means (money) enough—

closer.salute: Love to you, Mrs. B & the childerchildren
